plan.task: Understand Java ecosystem: JVM, JRE, JDK, and basic setup.
plan.cheat:
• Java is platform-independent
• JVM executes bytecode
• JRE = JVM + libraries
• JDK = JRE + dev tools

plan.task: Write and compile your first 'Hello World' program, understand main method and basic syntax.
plan.cheat:
• `public static void main(String[] args)` is entry point
• `System.out.println()` for console output
• Semicolons `;` terminate statements

plan.task: Take a self-assessment test on Java basics: ecosystem, 'Hello World' syntax, and compilation.
plan.cheat:
• Review definitions of JVM, JRE, JDK
• Practice writing a simple `main` method
• Understand the `javac` and `java` commands

plan.task: Learn primitive data types (int, float, double, char, boolean) and variable declaration/initialization.
plan.cheat:
• `int age = 25;`
• `float price = 19.99f;`
• `boolean isActive = true;`
• Choose appropriate type for data

plan.task: Study arithmetic, relational, logical, and assignment operators.
plan.cheat:
• `+ - * / %` (arithmetic)
• `== != > < >= <=` (relational)
• `&& || !` (logical)
• `=` `+= -= *= /= %=` (assignment)

plan.task: Read input from the console using the Scanner class and basic output formatting.
plan.cheat:
• `import java.util.Scanner;`
• `Scanner input = new Scanner(System.in);`
• `int num = input.nextInt();`
• `String text = input.nextLine();`

plan.task: Review all concepts from Day 1 to Day 6, focusing on variables, operators, and basic I/O.
plan.cheat:
• Go over notes on Java basics, data types, operator precedence, and using Scanner for input
• Practice small programs combining these elements

plan.task: Learn `if`, `else if`, and `else` conditional statements.
plan.cheat:
• `if (condition) { ... } else if (condition2) { ... } else { ... }`
• Conditions must evaluate to a boolean value

plan.task: Understand the `switch` statement and the importance of the `break` keyword.
plan.cheat:
• `switch (expression) { case value1: ... break; case value2: ... break; default: ... }`
• `break` prevents fall-through to next case

plan.task: Take a self-assessment test on conditional logic, operators, and variable usage.
plan.cheat:
• Practice writing programs that use `if-else` and `switch` statements
• Solve problems requiring logical decisions based on input

plan.task: Study the `for` loop syntax and common use cases.
plan.cheat:
• `for (initialization; condition; increment) { ... }`
• Ideal when the number of iterations is known beforehand

plan.task: Learn `while` and `do-while` loops, understanding their differences.
plan.cheat:
• `while (condition) { ... }` (checks condition before first iteration)
• `do { ... } while (condition);` (executes body at least once)

plan.task: Understand `break` and `continue` statements for controlling loop flow.
plan.cheat:
• `break;` immediately exits the innermost loop
• `continue;` skips the rest of the current iteration and proceeds to the next

plan.task: Review all concepts from Day 8 to Day 13, including conditional statements and all loop types.
plan.cheat:
• Revisit `if-else` vs `switch` decision making
• Practice choosing the correct loop type for different scenarios
• Understand the impact of `break` and `continue` on loop execution

plan.task: Declare, initialize, and access elements of one-dimensional arrays.
plan.cheat:
• `dataType[] arrayName = new dataType[size];`
• `arrayName[index]` to access an element (0-indexed)
• `arrayName.length` property for array size

plan.task: Define and call methods (functions), understanding parameters and return types.
plan.cheat:
• `public static returnType methodName(parameters) { ... return value; }`
• Methods promote code reusability and modularity

plan.task: Take a self-assessment test on arrays, loops, and basic method creation.
plan.cheat:
• Practice manipulating array elements (sum, min, max, search)
• Write methods that take parameters and return values, incorporating loops and conditionals

plan.task: Learn method overloading: defining multiple methods with the same name but different parameters.
plan.cheat:
• Compiler distinguishes overloaded methods by their signature (name + parameter types/order)
• Improves code readability by using a single name for similar operations

plan.task: Introduction to Object-Oriented Programming (OOP) concepts: Class, Object, Encapsulation, Abstraction, Inheritance, Polymorphism.
plan.cheat:
• Class (blueprint), Object (instance)
• Encapsulation (data hiding)
• Abstraction (simplification)
• Inheritance (is-a relationship)
• Polymorphism (many forms)

plan.task: Define custom classes, create objects, and understand instance variables and methods.
plan.cheat:
• `class MyClass { int x; String name; void myMethod() {} }`
• `MyClass obj = new MyClass();` (object creation)
• `obj.x = 10;` (accessing instance variables/methods)

plan.task: Review method overloading and the core principles of OOP (Class, Object, Encapsulation, Abstraction, Inheritance, Polymorphism).
plan.cheat:
• Understand why method overloading is useful
• Summarize each of the five core OOP principles with a small example
• Practice creating simple classes and objects

plan.task: Study constructors (default and parameterized) and the `this` keyword.
plan.cheat:
• Constructors initialize objects, have same name as class, no return type
• `this` keyword refers to the current object instance
• `this()` can call other constructors within the same class

plan.task: Understand Java's access modifiers: `public`, `private`, `protected`, and default (package-private).
plan.cheat:
• `public`: accessible from anywhere
• `private`: accessible only within the same class
• `protected`: accessible within the package and by subclasses
• Default (no keyword): accessible only within the package

plan.task: Take a self-assessment test on OOP basics: classes, objects, constructors, and access modifiers.
plan.cheat:
• Design classes with instance variables and methods
• Create objects using different constructors
• Apply appropriate access modifiers to fields and methods

plan.task: Learn inheritance using the `extends` keyword and the `super` keyword.
plan.cheat:
• `class Child extends Parent { ... }` (Child inherits from Parent)
• `super()` calls the parent class's constructor
• `super.method()` calls a method from the parent class

plan.task: Explore polymorphism: method overriding and runtime polymorphism (dynamic method dispatch).
plan.cheat:
• Overriding: redefining a superclass method in a subclass with same signature
• Use `@Override` annotation for clarity
• Runtime polymorphism: ability of object to take many forms at runtime

plan.task: Understand abstraction using abstract classes and abstract methods.
plan.cheat:
• `abstract class Shape { abstract void draw(); }`
• Abstract classes cannot be instantiated
• Abstract methods have no body and must be implemented by concrete subclasses

plan.task: Review Inheritance, Polymorphism, and Abstraction. Understand their real-world applications and differences.
plan.cheat:
• Differentiate between method overloading and overriding
• Explain the role of `super` and `this` in inheritance
• Understand when to use abstract classes vs. concrete classes

plan.task: Define and implement interfaces to achieve multiple inheritance of type.
plan.cheat:
• `interface Drawable { void draw(); }` (defines a contract)
• `class Circle implements Drawable { ... }` (provides implementation)
• Methods in interfaces are implicitly `public abstract` (Java 8+ allows default/static methods)

plan.task: Introduction to exception handling using `try-catch-finally` blocks.
plan.cheat:
• `try { riskyCode(); } catch (ExceptionType e) { handleException(); } finally { cleanUp(); }`
• `try`: block of code to monitor for errors
• `catch`: handles specific exception types
• `finally`: block that always executes
